The article of the land peace concerning belief can not do otherwise than to leave our dear confederates of the five cantons, Söllind and Wellind, in their old, unquestionable Christian belief, etc. They have it, and that is pleasing to us. Yes, they have it in twelve articles, as we have all been taught from childhood and we also have and abide by it; therefore we are not inclined to force anyone from it. And since we have always promised to hold fast to our belief according to the Scriptures of the old and new testament, we are not inclined in this established peace to give any belief good or bad (for the belief can not be given good or bad from these places, but with other grounds and from other places must be given good or bad), but only for the sake of peace and rest; since it thus happens that because of the belief there have arisen disputes and disagreements between us, such should be left, our dear confederates, to remain in their belief undisputed and undisturbed and especially in their old, unquestionable Christian belief, with the pure reservation that we, in like manner, remain undisturbed in our belief on their behalf.
But if it should happen that our dear confederates of the five cantons, with the form and pretense of the above mentioned article, should imagine that they could make our opinion good with it, as they have it with all circumstances before them, etc., and should attempt to hinder or take us captive, then we should leave it to the discretion and consideration of all to consider with what artifice, cunning and suspicion such a thing could be achieved by them; which we should not be able to do against them in order to make and keep such a pious, upright and lasting peace.
Therefore, everyone, even the less intelligent, can take and understand how badly we would be at peace if such an approach by our dear confederates of the five cantons, which they wish to have in our own countries and solely for our own benefit, were to be allowed to be deemed valid or invalid, etc.

Everyone, even those with poor understanding, can easily see and recognize that our dear Swiss confederates from the five cantons, who intend to have their own jurisdiction in our own lands, and only take action against us in accordance with our orders, should be allowed to do so, as long as they are not guilty of breaking the peace, and that we should be content with our reservation of faith that we may not and cannot have. For if we are to act according to our faith in our lands, courts, and jurisdictions against and with our own, it will inevitably happen (although we would keep the peace otherwise according to their wishes and desires) that we must be entirely silent about our faith and all its administration against our own, and not be able to take advantage of the reservation of faith that the peace treaty has stipulated and allowed for us no less than them.
And that we do not confess, hold, or preach any other faith than that the mass, which is used daily, is a true abuse of the institution of the Lord's Supper and an abomination before God, which is contrary to the reduction and abrogation of the death of Christ. Also, that the breaking of the sacraments, as the Pope practices them, is not supported by the scriptures or in accordance with the teaching of Christ. And that we are not saved by honoring our works, but by the sole faith before God, and many other points and articles, in which our faith cannot and will not be compared to their faith.
And that we, in all the things we have, do, and confess in these matters, do not cause anyone to abandon their purpose, much less be shamed, insulted, or disrespected, but rather out of good, honest, Christian awareness, that is, out of the administration and true intention of our faith, act and do as is done and used daily by us against those over whom we have power and authority, without interruption.
And since it is now clear that our dear Swiss confederates from the five cantons are in conflict and opposition in matters of faith and our understanding and awareness thereof, it is obvious what has caused the agreement of peace between the two sides: that each side should keep their faith and that we should come to peace and rest through such means, and also in terms of justice, as we have them in our own courts, jurisdictions, lordships, people and lands, remain and stay in unity and harmony, regardless of what each side practices or does in terms of their faith.

We must remain silent that the content of the article concerning our common lordship clearly shows that in the same, and not in one's own authorities and courts, one should let each party's faith be free and unchallenged and that none of the other should violate, damage or attack it and that if anyone does so, they should be punished and fined by a bailiff; from all of which it is obvious that we should not be challenged or interfered with in the administration of faith, as in common lordships, by the authorities and powers that are outside our common lordships in the said land peace and are established. Or else, the articles, which are agreed upon by both sides, would be in vain and fruitless for the sake of faith, and all the unrest would then have its origin and exercise as well as before, which the clear and explicit understanding of the land peace cannot tolerate or endure in all its articles; with the prayer that our Swiss confederates of the five orders should take it to heart and consider it well, etc.
It is not unreasonably required of us, since our sworn pound has retained us in the land peace and has given us, who were then governed, with lordships, freedoms, justice and other laudable customs of our administration, that our dear confederates of the five orders, without regard to the same, would not want to release us and impose on us, in what manner we should act and proceed with and towards our own in our own lands, courts and territories, that we should not be willing to impose them with regard to the articles of the peace.
But if there were to be found in our latest issued mandate or in our other commandments or prohibitions against our own, that we would name them, depict them or let them be known, that they should be driven from their faith in their lands and authorities and not tolerated, that they should be opposed to our faith with the named or handlotted ones, or that we had sent such mandate, commandment or prohibition to our dear lordships of our own and had written down to keep or take up according to the concluded peace (which does not happen), then our dear confederates would not be unreasonably to complain, as well as we have to complain about the Rhine mandate, in which it is forbidden to the evangelical preachers outside and contrary to the said ordinance of peace to do their teaching, which we have not been willing to tolerate out of respect for them and in accordance with the peace.
It is no secret that our dear confederates of the five orders remain steadfast, namely no one against any ceremony or usage of their faith, be it eating meat, cutting, plucking, the mass or other church customs, to speak or to proceed without punishment or permission, but to punish with body, goods or otherwise, how great a yoke that is against our faith and contrary to it, which we should equally complain about, no less than they. Yes, where such a thing is not allowed with the explicit reservation of the peace and is allowed to go and proceed against the theirs according to their well-consideration, then our dear confederates of the five orders should not complain about us on account of our behavior.

No one is hidden from our dear confederates of the five orders, abiding by the peace, namely no one against any ceremonies or customs of their faith, whether they be meats, garments, hats, mass or other church ceremonies, to speak or travel without being punished or tolerated, but punishing them with life, goods or other way, how great yoke this is to our faith and is against us, therefore we, no less than they, would have to complain about it.Yes, where such is not allowed with explicit reservation of peace and as well as to us against theirs according to their own pleasure and we should think to release our dear confederates' complaint and as those who have broken the peace, to stand to justice or to renew our due, lawful mandate, when we, alone for the furtherance of what we are minded towards God and out of his word, for and for the thorough report and approval of the Scriptures, old and new testament against them and mankind, are, and still are, etc., against ours with ungraspable mandates, writings, offers and commands, without any intention to insult or to despise anyone, handlotind?And that it is right and fair for them in their own sovereignty against our faith, that it should not be allowed to us in our sovereignties, and for the reason that it is not similar to their faith, abolished and forbidden, and we should be bound and obliged to stand to justice for it?
Whether it be fair, lawful or grounded and whether it be enough with it to keep peace and quiet, and to let everyone remain in his rights and that which pertains to him, yes, the higher peace of the country allows etc., we have willed to leave it to the consideration of all wise elders and those who are particularly instructed and authorized in the peace of the country, in trust.
Therefore, and since we have no other before us, but that we should leave our dear confederates of the five orders, as mentioned above, unpunished and unjudged, even (while they want it) undisputed and argued by their faith, it will, on the other hand, require all fairness, that they remain with us in the peace of the country according to our faith and in the administration thereof, against ours according to our will and pleasure, how we should allow and permit them such in their own sovereignties and countries, in the same way and measure, without question.
Since we are immediately and unswervingly minded to remain with the aforesaid, that our Christian faith may do and maintain support and succor towards and against ours, we will not change nor diminish our open knowledge of the faith, which we have opened in many open conversations, not to hurt or shame anyone, but for the sake of maintaining the honor of God, unless anyone from God's word, according to our offer, another report.

seg.output: We are determined to remain steadfast and unyielding in order to do what is necessary to uphold our Christian faith and to stand with and against our brethren, and to make known our open confession of faith which we have discussed in numerous open conversations, not for the purpose of reproach or shame, but to bring glory to God and to bear witness, not changing it or diminishing it unless someone brings us a different report from God's Word according to our offer. With special good and trusting hope, our beloved confederates will be pleased with our rightful actions and our sincere and well-founded reservation of our faith and be satisfied with their alleged grievances that they may draw from our mandates, we having thought of them therein or allowed them to go out for their sake, to make them and us peaceful and to do what may lead to peace and unity upon their humble offer. If such is not done upon our numerous offers, and we should be vexed and disturbed by such and similar interventions and approaches and forced, against our clear and pure common peace of the land, with such suspicious and suspicious circumstances, we would be obliged to seek means and ways by which we and ours could be protected and upheld in that which is vested and conceded to them by the five orders with letters and seals, and for which we had reserved the beginning of peace.

Since our subjects of the five orders would rather pay attention to their supposed claim, we would like to use the right according to the law of the people and consider such an important, large deal (for the sake of which one is to discuss in councils) finally to be settled by one man's decision and judgement, perhaps in the hope that it will fall to them and we must therefore give up our founded belief with considerable resistance and violation of our honour and abandon the track we have taken and learned from the truth etc., which is my opinion, the main cause for taking into consideration (nam id saxum volvit vulpecula illa mytrata, sui nomine pontificis).Therefore it is to be understood that one is not obliged to grant the right to them according to the law and the say of the people on all their claims.For if such a custom, especially at these times and runs, was to be allowed and each claim, however frivolous and unfounded it may be, was to be settled from that point on according to the graciousness by the decision or judgement of one man, to what extent and with what transgression, fraud and deceit the bad, pious and faithful examination of the people could be used, is easy to understand for all the wise, and the wrestlers are without a pound, then in a pound.Especially when one hangs on to the letter of the peace outside of legal and customary understanding and does not take the meaning from the preamble and subsequent articles and chapters, one should capture and allow.
Therefore it is necessary to send emissaries and messages to these places especially for this matter and to address and present them with all earnestness, so that it turns out that the five orders do not stand still or remain quiet for such their claim, so that one can guide them away from it friendly and kindly and remind them to live the pure and gentle peace and abandon such unfounded pursuit.Then, if they do not trust to keep it among themselves and we are of no other will than to remain firm etc., one would be compelled for need to require a clear declaration of the articles at first etc.

seg.output: At first and foremost, it is necessary to send messengers to the five cities in order to discuss this matter and to address them earnestly, so that it may be known that the five cities must not remain or be at rest in their current state. They should be kindly and courteously reminded to follow the law of peace and to abandon this unfounded accusation. If, however, they do not trust to maintain this, and we have no other will than to stand firm, it will become necessary to demand a clear explanation of the articles. If they should overcome this with the help of the mediators, which I do not believe they can do, then it should be the first rule to determine whether the peace treaty is accepted by the five cities and if they must answer and grant justice in respect to the request, if it is suitable for them. After that, the first rule should be established: whether the recently issued mandate from Zurich and the similar mandates are given to the peace treaty or not. In this way, the dispute could be settled and reconciled for a long time and in the meantime, various runs can be heard. Although I do not doubt that they are not obliged to yield to this accusation, and if we were to sit together with hearts and wills to promote God's honor and word, their purpose would not succeed. May God give them better news. Amen.

Therefore, if we were to handle matters in our lands, courts and jurisdictions in accordance with our faith in accordance with our mandates, be it with mandates, missives, commands, prohibitions, warnings, punishments against our governors, sub-governors, preachers or others who are obliged to us, and if, due to the split in faith between them and us, our Swiss from the five cantons were to take it upon themselves (as mentioned), being adorned and thus accused of breach of peace, as is currently intended by our recently issued mandate, then it would come to pass (if we were to keep the peace according to their desires and thoughts) that we would have to remain completely silent regarding our faith and all its management towards our own people, nor would we be able to be dealt with in this case under the terms of the peace treaty, which grants us no less than them.

seg.output: Wir sind daher entschlossen, stabhaft zu bleiben bei dem, was unserem christlichen Glauben und unserem Bekenntnis für Fürsorge und Erhaltung zuträglich ist. Dazu ist unsere offenkundige Erklärung des Glaubens, die wir in vielen, offenkundigen Reden ausgesprochen haben, nicht um jemanden zu beleidigen oder zu beschämen, sondern um die Ehre Gottes zu bekräftigen und bekannt zu machen, nicht zu ändern oder zu vermindern, es sei denn, dass uns jemand aus Gottes Wort, gemäß unserem Angebot, eine andere Darstellung bietet. Zu diesem Zweck, in der Hoffnung, dass unsere lieben Eidgenossen uns bei solch unserem rechtmäßigen Handeln unterstützen und mit der ehrlichen, wohlbegründeten Beibehaltung unseres Glaubens zufrieden sein werden, und ihre vermeintliche Beschwerde, die sie aus unseren Mandaten ziehen wollen, befriedigen, was auch immer wir für sie darin erwogen oder um ihretwillen ausgehen lassen haben, sie selbst und uns in Frieden lässt, und das tun, was auf ihr anfängliches Angebot zur Friedensstiftung und Einigkeit abzielen mag. Falls solches aber auf unserem so vielfältigen Angebot nicht geschieht und wir mit solch und dergleichen Eingriffen und Anfragen derart bedrängt und belästigt werden und mit solch verdrehten und verdächtigen Umständen von lauter und klarer Macht unseres gemeinsamen Landfriedens getragen werden, wären wir gezwungen, Mittel und Wege zu suchen, durch welche wir und die Unsrigen durch das, was sie uns mit Briefen und Siegeln bestätigt, gesichert und nachgegeben haben, und was wir uns anfangs des Friedens lauter vorbehalten haben, beschützt und erhalten werden könnten.

seg.output: Above all things, the mediators and the messengers of those places should be urgently requested and exhorted with all earnestness to ascertain in this matter, that the five parties shall not remain or be at peace in such their refusal, so that they may be kindly and courteously admonished thereof and reminded, that they may live in peace and harmony, and may lay aside such unfounded objections. But if they do not trust themselves to maintain the same, and we have no other will than to stand firm, then, for necessity’s sake, we should be constrained at first to require a clear explanation of the articles, etc. But if they should, by the mediation of the mediators, obtain such, as I do not expect, that we should give them any indulgence for such causes, then should this be the first judgment: whether the article of the peace shall oblige the address of the five parties, and whether they are obliged to give answer and right to those demands, such as they are accepted. After which judgment shall be pronounced, if the mandate lately issued from Zurich, and the like mandate, shall be applicable to the peace or not, etc. In this manner the affair may be prolonged and delayed for a long time, and in the mean time, all manner of artifices may be heard of.

seg.output: Above all, it is necessary to send envoys to the arbiters and the messengers of the same places for this matter, and to address and present them seriously, so that it is heard that the five orders may not remain still or quiet in their intent, so that one may turn them away kindly and amicably and remind them, so that they may live in peace and leave such unfounded attack. Then if they do not trust to maintain this among them, and we have no other will than to remain stiff, then, for necessity, one will be forced to require, at first, a clear explanation of the articles etc. If they should gain this with the consent of the arbiters, as I do not think that one can give them clemency for these causes, then it must be the first right for me, whether the peace in the land may accept the address of the five orders and whether they are obliged to answer and allow them right, if the latter are suitable. After this first right, it should be asked whether the mandate recently issued from Zurich and similar mandates will be given to the peace in the land or not, etc. In this way, the business could be arranged and reconciled for a long time, and in the meantime one could hear all kinds of news. Although I do not doubt that one is not obliged to let them go for this attack, and so one will sit together with heart and will to promote God's honour and word, their intention will not succeed. May God give better news.
